course.subject: IEDA
course.name: Introduction of Industrial Engineering and Decision Analytics
course.description: This course provides an introduction to industrial engineering and decision analytics (IEDA). It comprises of two parts. The first part introduces basic IE analytical tools, such as optimization, game theory, probability and statistics, at a conceptual level. In the second part, many of the IEDA practical concepts, including production and operations management, logistics and supply chain management, financial technology are introduced.

reviews.author: alphacarrot
reviews.title: Danger: Steep Drop
reviews.comment_content:
A comprehensive, yet very basic introduction to the various concepts of industrial engineering.
In each topic, only the most simplified model and one or two math formulas are discussed.
So just remember a few math formulas such as Little's Law and Critical Ratio are sufficient for most problems in the exams.

Course Schedule:

Week 1 Introduction to IE: What Is IE?
Week 2 Optimization
Week 3 Game Theory
Week 4 Probability Basics
Weeks 5-6 Process Analysis
Week 7 Project Management
Week 8 Midterm
Week 9 Waiting Line Management
Week 10 Supply Chain and Inventory Management
Week 11 Operations Strategy
Week 12 Revenue Management
Week 13 Financial Engineering
reviews.comment_teaching:
Most of the materials is so straightforward that one can understand them simply by self-studying the lecture slides at home.
However, WANG, Xin is a very good professor in terms of teaching. His accent is easy to understand. He explains things clearly. He maintains a constant pace throughout his lecture which is neither too slow nor too fast. He always finishes the last lecture slide around 3 minutes before class ends.
That is probably why his class attendance rate is over 90% even though attendance is not taken.
TA is also a very nice person, but the tutorials are not useful at all since the materials are so easy and well-explained during lecture.
reviews.comment_grading:
Since the content is very basic and there are many smart students, most grades are clustered around the 90% mark.
As a result, the curve is extremely steep between B and A range.
According to me and two of my friends, the curve from overall mark to course grade is as follows:
89% --> B+
90% --> A-
91% --> A

So be very careful in exams. One careless mistake can cost you one or two levels of grade!

Assignment: 10% (4 in total)
Online quiz: 10% (Full mark is given as long as they are completed on time)
Mid-term Exam: 40%
Final Exam: 40% (Cumulative on the syllabus, but this year only second half of the material was covered)
Bonus points: 3% for class participation
reviews.comment_workload: Not much workload except the four assignments, which do take some time. Marks are taken down for the smallest mistake, so be sure to double check your work. But these assignments do not make much difference in final grade anyway because their weightings are so low.

reviews.author: EMK
reviews.title: New content this sem
reviews.comment_content:
L1: Introduction
L2: Optimization
L3: Probability basics
L4: Project management
L5: Location analysis
L6: Inventory management
L7: Process selection and Facility layout
L8: Forecasting
L9: Revenue management

Be aware of L4, L5 and L6. Pay extra attention when doing questions of these topics or you will lose marks because of careless mistakes.

Lots of the contents were changed when compared with other semesters, I was faked by the reviews. Originally everything is similar to those in ISOM2700 but now only some of the topics are the same, sad.

To be honest, all the topics are not difficult so I guess everyone can handle them if enough attention is paid. The only thing that makes the different is your carefulness.

HOWEVER, there is a group project which you have to form a group of 5-6 by yourself. In the project, you have to study a real-world problem in Industrial Engineering and Decision Analytics. The following are the requirements:
– Clearly identify the problem you want to solve
– Explain the importance of your work
– Systematically describe the current practices
– Propose/develop promising solutions to the problem, and/or
   evaluate the consequences with the proposed solutions
Presentation and report are needed.

Because of the group project, it is strongly recommended that year 1 students SHOULD NOT take this course as one of your Engineering Introduction Courses. Don't take the risk of being free-rided (sadly I had a free-rider in my group). Another reason is that you will be killed if you are not careful enough during the exams.
reviews.comment_teaching:
This semester, there was only 1 lecture every week but the lecture lasts 2 hours.
The professor's English is quite good but sometimes she will not speak to her microphone when writing on whiteboard.Therefore, you can't hear what she is saying. Also, you can't see what has been written down on the board unless you take a photo. However, what she wrote on the board are the answers of in-class practice. NO answer is provided in PPTs so you have to jot them down carefully.

PPTs are quite orgainised and clear.

No attendance was taken for tutorials and I found them not very useful so skipped nearly all of them.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework: 10% ( take best 3 out of 4)
Participation: 5% (  should be in form of a sudden quiz)
Project: 15%
Midtern: 30%
Final: 40%

For exams, cheat sheet is allowed. Although the final is so-called cumulative, exactly what topic is included will be announced in exam review session.
Exams are not difficult but you have to be careful enough. You will have enough time for double check.

For project, I will say it is quite time-wasting. A lot of research have to be done so as to make your work sound. However, it is very likely that you will start your work 1 months before the final period. Therefore, it might be quite stressful.

No marks for final and project is released when grade was given.

Participation : 5/5
Homework : 10/10
midterm: 27/30 ( 90/100 mean 67.1/100 )

Letter grade: A-
should have no big problem on final so it should be due to my group project.
reviews.comment_workload:
Homework are quite light, only 4 homework for the whole semester.

Quite heavy workload on group project, it is strongly recommended that you should start your work early.

No much revision can be done, no past paper nor practice paper are given.

L7: Process selection

reviews.comment_workload:

Attendance for lectures is optional and having skipped a few lectures myself (reasons unspecified), I can say that catching up will take ~2-3 hours per lecture.

I do not regret taking this course despite the unfortunate grading incident

reviews.author: Caramel
reviews.title: Raised Engineering students' interest towards Business lol
reviews.comment_content:
I recommend DSE M1 people who've learnt basic calculus and probability stuffs like normal distribution probability to take this course. As for course content please go to the last review done by my classmate.
As a Y1 student who didn't take ECON/BAFS in DSE, I was bit
confused at the beginning and regretted of taking 2xxx course, especially the game theory (firm competition equilibrium was bit difficult for me to apply) but I overcome it with me interest towards optimization and business strategies.
The course content are so practical that they have solved my confusion in the past like why a company allows overbooking,why Disneyland have so many visitors though long queues are everywhere and how can suppliers make the best use of money and labors. I did feel like I am learning something I should learn as a university student and preparing for my career,if not,for the real world rules.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor WANG's teaching is the best among all the professors I have met in my 1st semester in UST. His English is comprehendable and he used key words& real life examples to link ideas and boost student's brainstorming&memorization.
(If you find it hard to digest the information, you should probably replay lectures afterward cuz your brain might have generated some questions you got confused)

TA's are so nice and helpful that they will reply your questions through email detially.(though they won't answer questions about assignment)
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignment(count the highest 3/4): 15%
Online quiz(unlimited attempts): 15%
Final Exam (in person): 70%   

Open notes final exam( make sure you do the pastpapers, apart from sample paper given)

70% is a lot of weight, I pass the exam but I was below mean few marks, I preview that I'll get B- but turns out is a B (all my assignment and quizes are almost full mark and on mean,fyi the mean is always higher than 9/10),so I think the course is good grade for me cuz my dedication and love towards this course got rewards.
reviews.comment_workload:
Not a lot of workload(as long as you don't have other courses having similar deadlines). 1 assignment/month, some online quizzes/week.
My friend who really good at probability and ECON didn't even have to replay every lectures/attend lectures but he did read every ppt,turns out he got higher grade than me.

Had no clue what was Industrial Engineering was before enrolling in the course. In the end thought a lot of it was quite interesting albeit not the traditional "engineering". For those who do not know what IEDA is about, you will be surprised.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Wang really tries hard to make sure you are able to understand the concepts and topics through a lot of different ways and even had a game set up in a class after the midterm so we could understand what one of the concepts were about. Sometimes hard to communicate with him as he might not understand your questions fully, but he will try his best to ensure you understand. Really helpful and nice and the lectures were mostly pretty good I thought although there is a lot of content. A lot of examples are done during class which reinforces all the content learned. The grading scheme pretty much forces student engagement which does make the class somewhat interesting.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignment: 10%
- The best 3 grades out of 4 assignments will be used
Online quiz: 10%
- Doesn't matter whether you get all correct answers or all wrong answers. As long as you complete them in time, you will receive full credit.
Class participation: 5%

Midterm exam: 35%
Final Exam: 40%

Finals: Mean = 29.35/40; S.D. = 6.15

Just complete the quizzes on time (you could just randomly click on different options and you would still get full credit).

reviews.title: Great course
reviews.comment_content:
Have a look at the syllabus attached below.

Contents are well-organized, as the prof mentions many topics but only touches on the most basic concepts and related formulas, which is just enough for most students but also intriguing for the ones wishing to take on higher IEDA courses. The course really gave me a new outlook on what Industrial Engineering is.

Most lectures include some theoretical concepts, derived formulas and example problems. Really similar to a high school math lecture, just with more applied topics, thus making the course very student-friendly. Apart from those, prof sometimes gives example from real-life Industrial Engineering, which makes the lectures more insightful.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Wang Xin has a mainland accent but quite easy to follow. He gives clear explanation of concepts and is very willing to answer lots of questions from students, which actually seems to annoy some people as his lectures get disrupted by continuous questions :D

Tutorials would often summarize main concepts and then solve applied math problems. TAs' pronunciation are not really good but they are also really willing to help out.
reviews.comment_grading:
Online quizzes: 15%
Assignments (best 3 out of 4, 5% each): 15%
Final exam: 70%

Online quizzes are very simple, mostly contents straight off the slides. You are given unlimited attempts so make sure to get full 15% before the deadline.

Assignments are not hard. It is crucial to review the last year's assignments' sample solution so you know what to write in your answers. Try not to make simple calculation mistakes.

Final exam: Well this seems to be the problem with the course. Even 3 hrs won't be enough for you to solve very long questions which are even harder than the assignments and contain many steps to go through (as previous reviews say, maybe this is a "anti-cheating measure"). I was really shocked after not being able to finish the exam since the previous quizzes and assignments are much easier. I understand that the TAs are also willing to give points as long as you show some effort but it was really difficult.

P/S: Seems like grades are also very competitive. One mistake on the final exam can cost you a lot.

My grades:
Online quizzes: 15 (very high mean, I think must be approx 14.87)
Assignment 1: 7.2 (mean 8.26) (I submitted this one late and screwed up the calculations, it was actually very easy)
Assignment 2: 10 (mean 9.19)
Assignment 3: 10 (mean 9.32)
Assignment 4: 10 (mean 8.8)
Final: 59 (mean 40.8)
Total: 89
Grade: A
reviews.comment_workload: Very light, concepts can be grasped with ease, you only need to be careful not to miss the quizzes and assignments. No extra work needed after class. Also, try to study carefully for the hard questions in previous final papers.

reviews.author: itsrocky
reviews.title: Fantastic Course!
reviews.comment_content:
I would highly recommend this course for students looking to start their own businesses, or seeking to work in a management position in a business.

Industrial Engineering is sometimes known as "The Science of Better." Better in the sense that you can run your business better and more efficiently.

This course provides a high-level overview on various problems one may encounter in a business, as well as solutions/techniques to resolve them.

Wang Xin touched on the following topic areas during the semester:
- Game Theory
- Probability
- Productivity
- Waiting Lines (Queues)
- Inventory Management
- Revenue Management
- Demand Forecasting
- Supply Chain Management
- Quality Management
- Financial Engineering

You are only taught the basics for each concept, just enough to intrigue you should you be interested in the subject.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Wang Xin is an engaging lecturer. He does occasionally read off the slides but he is very proactive in answering questions.

He's a former Tsingua and UT Austin graduate with a wealth of operations research experience under his belt.
reviews.comment_grading:
Final Exam: 70%
Assignment: 15%
Online Quiz: 15%
reviews.comment_workload:
We had a total of 4 assignments and 8 quizzes throughout the semester.

The assignments are doable, I would suggest that students go through the "Old Assignments" folder on Canvas in which the TAs post the questions and marketing schemes for assignments in the previous year.

The quizzes are very easy provided that you know the material. Quizzes are in a MCQ format with unlimited attempts.

reviews.author: 69verynice
reviews.title: Very nice course, recommended
reviews.comment_content:
Basically operation management. I have zero business background but still found this course manageable and fun to learn. According to my relative with business background, the content included in the course is not 'basic', but 'simple' enough that everyone can handle it.

Expected Learning Outcomes and Course Objectives
•Obtain a basic ability to apply mathematics and engineering knowledge to formulate and optimize an operation of a business.
•Obtain a basic knowledge of industrial engineering, production, logistics and supply chain management and the related contemporary issues.
•Understand the impact of engineering solutions in a global and societal context and on a broad range of issues, including environmental and social responsibilities.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Both prof and TAs are the best. They are patient and willing to answer all of your question, and their explanation is helpful.
I feel like the IE department have too few students, cuz prof often promote their department in lecture. Just like watching Ads before watching a YouTube video, as long as the main content is awesome, it is not a big deal.
reviews.comment_grading:
No Mid-term. Grading is fair but not as good as expected. Maybe the course is too easy, everyone manage to get a high score. The mean and SD of final exam are 74% and 16.7% respectively. My result was 0.5 SD above mean(~82%) and got almost full mark in quizzes and assignments, but got a B+ only at the end. I guess A range requires at least 85% in final, not easy.

Grading Scheme
Assignment: 15%
Online quiz: 15% (Out of class and have infinite attempt, basically guaranteed full mark)
Final Exam: 70%
Bonus points: 3% for class participation
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite light.
There are four assignments in total, each of them take up to 2 hours to finish, it is easy to find similar example from ppt slides so don't worry about it. Quizzes are just a few basic conceptional questions. But the exam is a bit challenging, some questions are trickier than examples provided in class. Tho it is an exam so it is normal to be harder than normal practice right?

reviews.author: Flynn ZHANG
reviews.comment_content:
This is a course mainly designed for year 1 students. It introduces the basic concepts and some simple models about Industrial Engineering. The maths in this course is not difficult at all.
This course is devided into two parts. One is the basic concepts and tools such as game theory and basic probability, the other is the simple applications of those above, including queueing theory, project management, supply chain management and so on.
Generally, they are not hard to understand.
reviews.comment_teaching:
He taught in a very humorous way, trying to introduce every concept as detailed as possible. Although he did not check attendance at any time, it was good to attend every class to get a deeper understanding about the contents in his ppt. Besides, every week he might introduce different fields of Industrial Engineering, so it would be easy to get lost if you skipped even one single time.
He is always willing to answer any questions at any time. You can find him easily at his office after class. He also replies emails swiftly.
reviews.comment_grading:
It mignt be helpful if you often go to find him and let him know your name.
The tests are fair and comprehensive.
I got around mean in midterm and around 1 SD higher than mean in final, receiving a B+ at last.
reviews.comment_workload:
No workload.
There are only four assignments, each of which is not hard and may not take too much time. If you have problem, you can seek him or TAs for help at any time. It mignt be great if you have a friend to do the assignments together.
Online quizzes are also graded, but you will get full marks as long as you finish them in time regardless of correctness.

reviews.author: sancho
reviews.title: Fairly good
reviews.comment_content:
The course gives a pretty good general understanding of what industrial engineering is. The content is quite wide, covering some interesting commonly occurring problems - like, how to predict the length of a queue before a counter. However, since it is an introductory course, one may feel the knowledge they get is rather superficial, as the course does not suggest mathematical derivation of the formulae used. Nevertheless, It still requires some basic math knowledge because calculus will be used a couple of times (A-level is more than sufficient).

The presentations are good enough, but some grammatical errors may put you off a little

Overall the content taught is interesting but quite commonsensical and easy to understand

Course Schedule
Week 1 Introduction to IE: What Is IE?
Week 2 Optimization
Week 3 Game Theory
Week 4 Probability Basics
Weeks 5-6 Process Analysis
Week 7 Project Management
Week 8 Waiting Line Management
Week 9 Supply Chain and Inventory Management
Week 10 Midterm (Cover Materials in Weeks 1-7)
Week 11 Operations Strategy
Week 12 Revenue Management
Week 13 Financial Engineering
reviews.comment_teaching:
The instructor was kind and friendly, but appropriately strict too. He tries to answer all the questions asked and nicely explains the content. The slides carry enough information, but lectures do help to better absorb it

There is a significant problem with the English level, unfortunately, as he may not be able sometimes to find the words to answer a question or explain a concept in details.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignment: 10%
Online quiz: 10%
Class participation: 5%
Mid-term Exam: 35% (It will cover all the materials before the mid-term)
Final Exam: 40% (Comprehensive, with an emphasis on the second half)

Simply answering quizzes in due time gives you a full mark

It is quite easy to get a good grade, but some questions on exams ask you to memorize definitions

However, TAs may sometimes deduct marks for ridiculous "mistakes" - like forgetting a dollar sign at the end of the solution
reviews.comment_workload:
4 assignments and weekly quizzes are all you have to do

Preparing for mid-terms/finals is nothing special

reviews.author: Mango Pudding
reviews.title: Actually quite interesting (But beware, requires basic differentiation and integration)
reviews.comment_content:
Syllabus:
- Intro to IE
- Optimisation (Linear programming)
- Game theory, Nash equilibrium, Cournot model
- Probability (Discrete, continuous, normal distribution)
- Process analysis (Little's Law)
- Project management (Structure, critical path, time-cost model)
- Waiting line management (Kingman's equation)
- Inventory management (Economic order quantity model, safety stock, newsvendor model)
- Revenue management (Two-segment problem, overbooking)
- Forecasting
- Supply chain management (Bullwhip effect)
- Quality management (Six-sigma, process capability index)
- Financial engineering

I didn't intend to take this course at first with this being a replacement for another course, but this turned out to be quite interesting. Never been interested in business before but this is unexpectedly intriguing. It also answered questions one may ask themselves on business practices like why overbooking occurs when customers may be dissatisfied, why Disney uses fast passes (not anymore when they now charge a premium for it), why more lanes cause more traffic.

It might take some time to fully understand and master some portions of the course (particularly I struggled with Cournot model at first), but with the help of TAs, you could grasp it sooner or later.

Having prior M1/M2 knowledge (only basic differentiation and integration are relevant) is conducive to understanding Cournot model, continuous probability distribution and optimal order quantity, but not really a necessity.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Wang is a great instructor, he was well prepared for every lecture, with additional anecdotes and real examples on top of the standard presentation. Has a slight accent but is comprehensible. He is very willing to answer questions raised during class, and would further explain with examples on the whiteboard if it stumped many students. A quiet classroom is required or else he wouldn't proceed, which is fair, to be honest.

It is much better to be on campus for this course. I've watched the zoom replay once and the audio is hardly intelligible plus the writings on the whiteboard is barely visible (since the classroom camera is computer-controlled and didn't zoom into the content).

Tutorial sessions summarise key points in the previous topic and then solve applied math problems. Though the TA conducting tutorials is difficult to understand (both pronunciation-wise and volume-wise).

TAs are very helpful and are rapid in responding to emails. Just ask them whenever you are stuck.
reviews.comment_grading:
- Assignment: 15% (Best 3 out of 4)
Max 10 marks for each assignment, I got [9, 10, 9.7, 9.6], and the mean is [8.26, 9.19, 9.32 8.8], so be meticulous when attempting them. They take quite a while to mark and release feedback for assignments, but marking schemes will be released much earlier than that.

- Canvas quiz: 15%
Unlimited tries thus you should be able to get full marks here. There will be one for each topic, remember to check Canvas.

- Final exam (in person): 70%
Open notes open book, thank goodness, just print everything you need, though it was an INTENSE 3-hour exam with ~10 short questions (which notes come in handy) and then ~8 long questions (with many subquestions) involving an ample amount of calculation. It was pretty challenging both time-wise and difficulty-wise. I got 56/70, and the mean is 40.34.

- "Bonus points": 3% for class participation, listed in the syllabus, but Prof. Wang did once say he doesn't care about bonus points and thus is redundant.

In the end, I got an A for this course.
reviews.comment_workload:
Four assignments and eight quizzes in total.

Assignments may take some time to complete, but an abundant amount of time was provided for each one, and don't wait till just before the deadline. Usually 3-5 questions (w/ subquestions). I recommend going through the "Previous assignments" folder on Canvas, where you might find some clues on how to tackle your assignment. Though obviously the questions would be different and it may not aid you at all. Also, thoroughly check your calculation!

Canvas quiz for each topic, and are very easy, plus unlimited attempts allow you to try until you fully grasp it.

reviews.author: DuckAndChips
reviews.title: Reasonable workload, may be difficult for people who are not confident in mathematics
reviews.comment_content:
Please refer to the attachment for a more detailed look at the syllabus.

Industrial engineering is the study of making operations and processes better (broadly speaking). The course starts with introducing some basic math concepts such as game theory and probability, which helps us understand the following lectures talking about mathematical models for different processes, such as projects, waiting line, supply chain, revenue etc.

The difficulty can be intimidating for students who are not confident in mathematics because the application of mathematical models makes up most of the content of the course. It is, however, not impossible to grasp these concepts after sufficient practice and research. As a person who is not confident yet not intimidated by mathematics, I had to search up some videos on YouTube to fully grasp the concepts.

Lecture notes are easy to understand.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor elaborates from the lecture notes and derives/demonstrates different mathematical models. He is also very keen to answering questions in class, and provides good explanation to even very minor/meaningless (i'm sorry) questions - which can become quite annoying for students like me who wants to focus on the materials being taught. One good thing also is that the professor is generous in providing practice questions for us. He also has a mainland accent.

Although attendance is not being recorded, I do encourage reviewing his lecture videos (on 2x speed) when you are unable to attend his lectures on time. Not that his lectures are that good, but that it's difficult to understand the concepts without explanation, for me at least.

reviews.author: Vegetable
reviews.title: Nice Course and Good Teaching
reviews.comment_content: Well, just some basic concepts about optimization in many different aspects. To be honest, it is more like an intro course in SBM rather than SENG, but I am pretty sure that you can learn some interesting knowledge by taking this course. The professor will introduce some basic mathematical tools (mainly about probability) before getting to the models that need them, so don't worry about the pre-knowledge you need for this course.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Wang is really nice. Although he is from mainland, his verbal English is much better than "acceptable" compared to some other teachers. For the students from mainland like me, it is quite easy to follow him, and I am sure that for students from other regions, they can also enjoy his lecture. Professor Wang likes students to ask questions of whatever kind at whatever time, and he will stop and answer your question patiently. The TAs are also very nice, though their English might not be as good as Professor Wang's. Just repeat your questions and they are willing to stay.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quiz: 15%
Homework: 15%
Final: 70%
Participation bonus: 3% (earned by asking questions)

For the quiz, as long as you finish them with whatever marks, you can get all scores. There are 4 hw in total, and the 3 best out of 4 will be taken for the score calculation. Besides, there are past homeworks with standard solutions for your reference. Make good use of them, and it is also easy to get the full mark.

The most important thing is definitely the final!!! Professor Wang's anti-cheating manner is simple but very effective: overwhelming questions. In the three hours, you have to finish an exam paper composed of 9 pages, which covers all the topics except for financial engineering and quality management in the whole semester. You can have a toilet break at any time with prior notification to the proctor, but I would suggest you to pee in your pants because the time is so precious. The grading for the final is very nice. The TAs have tried their best to give you score as long as the logic is correct.

The overall grading is nice, I got full marks in hw and quiz, and 63/70 in final (Mean: 51.88 SD 11.64) with letter grade A in the end, so I think it is pretty satisfactory.
reviews.comment_workload: Pretty low. Just finish the homework on time, and do some reviewing before the final. Everything shall be fine.

reviews.comment_content:
Week 1 Introduction to IE: What Is IE?
Week 2 Optimization
Week 3 Game Theory
Week 4 Probability Basics
Weeks5-6 Process Analysis
Week 7 Project Management
Week 8 Waiting Line Management
Week 9 Supply Chain and Inventory Management

The first 6 weeks would seem to be very easy if you have some understanding in statistics, which I assume everyone does. Starting from the 7th week, however, the course would accelerate, about double the previous speed. The concepts would play a major role, while for the first 6 weeks mathematical tools are more important.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Wang is very good at teaching. He has a Chinese accent, after all, he graduated from Tsinghua EE. But it is understandable. Also, he goes into the concepts in a very detailed sense, which is very good.
The only problem for teaching is that the bonus points are wanted by everyone. So stupid questions come out and interrupt the class. I hate it personally.

bonus 3% participation

The reason why I do not add "quiz" is because the online quizzes would be given full mark as long as you decide to do them. Homework are to be selected the best 3 out of 4 homework. Thus the only thing that matters is the final. Get well prepared and well practiced, then it would not be difficult to get over the mean if you feel the same way as I do in the CONTENT part.
